history.content:
That's not how PhDs work. You are given a PhD when the dissertation committee finds your work of passable quality and allows you to graduate. You are not judged based on the number of publications.

Work that you put in towards publications will definitely go well in a dissertation, and journal-quality work will definitely make a dissertation committee happy, but graduating and publishing papers actually have very little to do with each other.

I'm looking for areas to go into and I'm curious about the graduation requirements for Ph.D. on AI systems (e.g. in RISELab). I know that for other deep learning related areas, Ph.D. students need to publish many papers per year in order to graduate. However, in terms of AI systems, publication does not come this frequent. I wonder whether this means the graduation requirement will be higher (since it's hard to get to same amount of publications/influence)? If not, could anyone provide a comparison between the graduation requirements?
history.subject: Graduation requirements for Ph.D. in Machine Learning systems
